title: GitHub CEO on the AI Coding Arms Race: One Agent, 150M+ Devs

the very beginning. How are you
repositioning with this agent launch?
Over the last year it has clearly turned
out to be you know that you know race
between uh a co-pilot curser and
windsurf. We believe we still you know
have the biggest user base across these
three. As with every competition whether
it's in sports or elsewhere you
constantly need to keep reinventing
yourself. The race is on.
[Music]
Thomas, welcome to the show. Thank you
for having me. Great to have you here.
Um, psyched to get to talk to you about

that's awesome the place I want to start

which we actually three different uh

then autocomp completion or you know

that's that's how this all started uh 5

We are we are part of you know the um
the developer ethos, the developer

into um
customization code search. Um bringing

I think that journey uh will continue

the co-pilot experience between the IDE
um and the the DevOps life cycle. I
think maybe what I'm what I'm asking is
um you guys you had the developer

like right at the edge of what all the

like tons of stuff in the in the

What's been going on for the last couple

Well, look, if you you know go back a
year um to last build um 2024 um at that
time uh you know the those those
competitors were still um you know in a
in a group of competitors and it was
always clear there's going to be a

with us with us being the number one uh
that that created that market and um we
knew that you know at some point as
everything in technology right like
Windows versus Mac or iPhone versus
Android and and whatnot there's always a
a you know two or three players that

year it has clearly turned out to be you
know that you know race between uh a
co-pilot um curser and windsurf um we
believe we still you know have the
biggest uh uh user base uh across these
three. And um uh as with every

or elsewhere, uh you you constantly need
to keep reinventing yourself. You know,
just because you won, you know, the
championship or in the season this year
doesn't mean you're going to win next
year. And so I think for us the the most
important thing is that we're able to to
move really fast. Um we we shipped um uh
over 100 uh things uh change locks uh
for co-pilot just yet now in 2025 and
it's only May and we're going to keep
shipping and we're going to you know uh
evolve our platform from uh VS Code
where we announced today that that
Copilot is going to be open source but
we also have Xcode support and jet
brains and then Eclipse and and and and
of course the the old school visual
studio uh all the way into our platform
where not only have the coding agent we
have a code review agent And uh we have
an autofix agent that fixes security
vulnerabilities. And you can actually
already stitch them together and have um
one agent create the pull request and
the next agent review the pull request
and look at uh security vulnerabilities
and then have the the SIE agent monitor
your cloud resources. So I think the the
race is on and we're excited about the
competition because we ultimately uh
believe in developer choice. It's great
that there's, you know, many tools out
there, uh, and developers have the
choice and they can, you know, pick the
editor that that fits fits them best.
And then, as you mentioned, uh, they're
still coming to GitHub and store that
code there and then hopefully use
Copilot as part of that of of part of
that journey. Yeah. Tell me about the
C-pilot agent you just launched. like
tell me about the architectural and
product and UX decisions that you made
and why you think it's a better agent
solution than maybe like you know codeex
or uh some of the other um more popular
agents on the market right now. It all
starts um with GitHub actions and I
already mentioned earlier we um brought
actions to market u back in 2018. What
are actions for people? Get actions is
um uh you know conceptually uh is uh you
can understand it as um our our way of
implementing continuous integration
continuous deployment um or or simpler
um it's um you have a trigger um you
know new commit a new issue new pull
request or comment on a pull request and
there's lots of these uh triggers that
you can define that then runs a script
uh on a compute uh instance aka virtual
machine um and uh github actions offers
you that uh integrated into into GitHub.
Um and so you can define uh within the
repository a workflow file. It's a YAML
file and you say okay on every commit I
want to run you know this build script
or this test script. Um and this actions
ecosystem. So it's developer automation
if if you if you will, right? Like you
can run something uh on an on an event.
Every time you push code back something
for you or say this pull request um uh
uh breaks the tests and so you're not
allowed to merge that back into the main
branch. And that ecosystem has now
existed um for almost 7 years and has
over 25,000 actions within our
marketplace. And so the cool thing about
actions is that you can compose it from
other actions. And so there's actions
for everything that you can imagine
including uh for what it's worth also
lots of AI scenarios um connecting to to
model APIs and um a lot of uh open
source projects and enterprise customers
are using actions for their for their
engineering stack um for their for their
platform um and so we have that compute
layer available and customers already
trusting that compute layer right
because ultimately what happens is that
whenever you run actions you're cloning
your source code your intellectual
property onto something else, right? A
comp a virtual machine and then you're
trusting that that virtual machine, you
know, exists during the runtime of your
script. And then when the the virtual
machine uh when the script is done, then
the virtual machine gets shut down and
and everything gets deleted. And so
you're not having your source code set
outside of you know your compliance
boundary or your your permissions uh uh
who has access to that codebase. So we
think that's one of the advantages of
our agent that we're already integrating
it into the existing ecosystem where
people are already running their their
CI/CD. Um the second thing is that we
believe that the best place for agents
uh to exist is where developers already
do their work. And so uh you know we
already mentioned the IDE with VS Code.
So you can just trigger uh the coding
agent uh from copilot uh chat in VS Code
and say at GitHub you know create a pull
request to add tests uh you know to the
method that that has wrote. Um, and then
that spins it off in in the background.
Uh, and it does its thing on GitHub
actions and it opens a draft pull
request. Um, describes what the plan is.
Um, and then commits changes into that
pull request. And that's very similar to
how you would delegate, you know, a task
to one of your co-workers, right? So,
you're basically taking the exact same
workflow that you're already doing with
your team and applying it to agents and
and bringing those two worlds together.
And that also means that you know three
years from now you can go back to that
pull request and it doesn't matter
whether a pull request came from a human
developer or from an agentic developer.
What matters is that you have still
everything together in one place. And it
also means that you know you have a
session log uh that is stored together
the repo. So again that session log
survives you know as long as you like.
You have audit logging so you know when
the agent started its work and it
stopped its work and lots of enterprise

into their threat intelligence so they
can kind of like monitor uh you know a
lot of the questions we're getting is
how do you do how do I trust the agent u
in contrast to CI/CD where you have a

maybe a library run tests you know uh
upload the test results into the log
file with agents that process is not

uh inherently non-deterministic and

believe this integration of the agent in
the same workflow that your team is

because you don't have to relearn uh how

you're testing code, how you're

Like you you're trying things out

One of the I mean I think there there's

today we call it product like growth um

right? So and uh that actually goes as
